nodes.bodyText: As pointed out in #533 , I think there should be some handling here.

That was my first instinct as well. As far as I can tell, this is however not necessary.
I understand the lifecycle as follows:

the JobExecutor is started via JobExecutor#start

the acquisition runnable is created but not started
ManagedJobExecutor#startExecutingJobs is called and instructs the ManagedExecutorService to start the acquisition runnable (it allocates a Thread for that, it keeps on running until we stop it)


the JobExecutor is stopped via JobExecutor#shutdown

the acquisition runnable is stopped and thereby marked as interrupted in a flag
the SequentialJobAcquisitionRunnable#runAcquisition loop running in SequentialJobAcquisitionRunnable#run is interrupted, the acquisition runnable stops
the ManagedExecutorService frees the Thread it used for the acquisition runnable because that runnable stopped and returns the Thread to its pool of idle Threads



If I understand that lifecycle correctly, there shouldn't be anything left for us to do here. Please correct me if I missed something here.

Yes, I see what you mean. It seems that from the behaviour of the shutdown of the JobExecutor itself , the runnable is already stopped, so there is no need to implement anything specific for the stopExecutingJobs method.
Thanks for having a look at this 👍
